ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Revision of songs, knowledge of the music industry, perspectives of successful industry professionals, a network of musicians at Yale
Incredible course. We need more pop music courses at yale.
how to approach writing pop music and how to devvelop yourself as an artist
Formulas to songwriting and production, particularly through the lens of what constitutes a hit pop song

Coming into this class with some experience writing songs for fun but nothing serious, I learned how to put together something that I could use for professional purposes. From class discussions and guest speakers, I learned about the music industry and where I might fit in if I were to pursue it as a career. Lastly, I learned how to co-write and work with my peers on music. It felt like a real window into the industry.
developed my songwriting process and goals.

I greatly improved my songwriting abilities and branched out into styles/genres. Learned a lot about melodic math, writing more compelling lyrics, cutting down a song draft to make it more compact, leaning into your intuitions when revising. All incredibly helpful tools.

This course provided me with basic, critical knowledge and insight about navigating the music industry as an artist. It helped me to establish a songwriting routine, pushed me to collaborate with others, and helped me to solidify my understanding of songwriting structures and approaches to making music.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the most valuable part of the course was sharing and critiquing each others work, but the readings and external materials could have been incorporated more if the class were to align exactly with its description. However, I think a lot of the readings stand alone well and the class was extremely informative on its own.
Incredible prof.
Mike has an electric personality and consistently engages with students in a matter that is both casual but informative

The strength has to be the people. Professor Errico assembled the most impressive group of musical students at Yale. It was amazing to work with and constantly be surrounded by such talented peers, who definitely inspired and pushed me to complete my best work. Prof. Errico also brought in great guest speakers who offered expertise in many different parts of the industry.

The weakness of this class was probably its size. Because there is so much great work to discuss and listen to, the class doesn't always workshop your song each week. If you really want to be featured, you can make it happen, but otherwise, for people like me who were a little less confident, you won't necessarily get too much-individualized attention.
good course, i think enrollment could be more selective so that the average music quality is higher and each student gets a little more focus.

The class was truly phenomenal all around. In the beginning of the semester we were visited by several guests who are in the songwriting/entertainment industry who has some very valuable experiences and insights to share. The one downside was that there was less time for us to listen to each other's songs and give each other feedback, but we did have more time for this later in the semester!

One major strength of this course is Professor Errico himselfhe's so generous with his time, and is incredibly supportive of his students. His feedback was attentive, generative, and kind, and I appreciate that while this class may be geared toward a particular kind of songwriter, he was willing to encourage and make space for differing approaches to writing, artistry, and sound. 

Another major strength of this course is the resources and connections it provides. Professor Errico brought in a number of speakers who were both wise and willing to be of help in the future, and always encouraged us to reach out to them (and to him) for guidance. This kind of connection means a lot in an industry that can feel really tough to crack, and I'll certainly be keeping those resources in mind. 

In terms of weaknesses, I sometimes felt that class time could be more intentionally structured / organized.
Best course ever and couldn't be better

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was able to collaborate and share music well even in a virtual format.
Naturally it wouldve been fantastic to be able to collaborate with fellow students and communicate in class in person but I think Mike was able to execute the zoom medium very very strongly
This was a great class, and I can only imagine how much more fun/better it would have been in real life rather than over Zoom.
It worked pretty well.
Successful utilization of screen and audio sharing to share songs and lyric sheets.
For a songwriting class, this course translated surprisingly well on zoom. Obviously nothing can replicate playing live together, but for what it was, I think zoom and box were utilized really well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to any student seriously interested in songwriting. If a student isn't interested in songwriting as a career or at least a serious hobby, the class would be much less helpful.
Absolutely. This class is what got me through the semester. I loved Prof. Errico and everything about this curriculum. Please bring him back.
Absolutely without a doubt. This was up there with the best classes that I have taken, and Ive green some invaluable experience in this class that I wouldnt have otherwise gotten

Absolutely. This was an extremely rewarding class, and perhaps most importantly, an amazing opportunity to meet some amazing musicians at Yale. If you want to make music/write songs, there is no better class out there.
Absolutely, if interested in songwriting.

Absolutely! This a perfect course for any musician or songwriter who's looking for a chance to hone their craft outside of the classical and jazz traditions that dominate so much of music in education.

Yes!! If you're looking to write more regularly, be part of a music community, and learn about the music industry, this is a wonderful course. But if you aren't willing to be creation-oriented, maybe look elsewhereit's a lot of creating to do on an academic timeline, which can be difficult!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In person collaborations
weekly zoom seminar.
n/a
